Ted Striker.Action: Drops the flag and rushes out after taxiing a businessman, indicating willingness to help and promptness.
Keeps walking and avoids a Zealot pinning a flower on his jacket by slipping out of his coat, showing dismissal and avoidance rather than friendliness.
Actively seeks to talk to Elaine to resolve their issues, expresses willingness to work things out and asks for patience.
Fails to realize Elaine no longer respects him, indicating a lack of awareness of his relationship problems.
Promises Elaine he can change, showing sincerity and hope.
Glares with determination after Elaine leaves, indicating persistence.
Punches a religious zealot who tries to pin a flower on him without looking.
Asks if Elaine Dickinson is on the flight, showing concern for her presence.
Musters courage to board the plane despite terror from war recollections.
Purchases a ticket smoking section without complaint, polite interaction with check-in.
Approaches check-in counter to buy ticket showing initiative to board the plane.
Forgets to bring baggage despite traveling, potentially showing a minor oversight.
Freezes in terror and agonizes over war recollections before boarding, indicating hesitation and anxiety affecting competence.
Musters courage and proceeds toward airplane despite fear, showing some level of bravery and resolve.
Politely thanks Randy after ticket is taken.
Replies honestly to Mrs. Elderly about being nervous.
Acknowledges his nervousness but maintains composure while boarding and sitting down, interacts politely with attendant.
Mentions having been a pilot during the war, implying past competence.
Appears nervous looking out the window and openly admits nervousness when asked.

Approaches Elaine to talk despite her reluctance.

Shows awkwardness or distraction when a woman nearby hangs herself unnoticed while he talks, revealing a lack of awareness of his surroundings.
Embraces Elaine passionately, expresses love sincerely despite upcoming dangerous mission.
Expresses concern and seriousness about leading an important mission, indicating awareness and responsibility.
Appears bored while on the plane, possibly disengaged or distracted.
Tries to reconcile with Elaine and asks her to hear him out, expressing a desire to return to better times.
Reflects on past emotional moments sincerely, showing vulnerability and longing for connection.
Appears withdrawn and troubled by past trauma, struggling with living in the past.

Attempts to reconcile with Elaine and expresses a desire for a better future.
Remembers crashing his fighter plane after being warned he was too low.
Recovers sufficiently to be cleared of blame for the raid, implying some measure of competence.
Expresses deep remorse and sorrow for his mistake causing death of comrades.
Allows Sgt. McCobb to take a break from posing for his painting, showing practical consideration.
Shows despondency and self-blame, which could indicate introspection but not necessarily warmth.
Identifies Lieutenant Hurwitz's condition as severe shell shock and understands his delusion.
Politely refuses coffee service.

Admits he couldn't bring himself to take a job at Boeing, showing vulnerability and understanding of Elaine's desire for a career.
Reflects on past job offers and personal failures, indicating he couldn't bring himself to take a reasonable job at Boeing.

Hesitates but ultimately agrees to assist with flying duties despite personal doubts.

Admits he hasn't flown any kind of plane in six years and expresses concern about flying a plane very different from his military single-engine experience.
Turns to face the controls and is identified by Dr. Rumack as the only person on the plane who can possibly fly it, indicating trust in his ability despite his doubts.
Is described as someone who 'felt too much inside' and 'ate his heart out over every name on the casualty lists.'
Failed to perform under pressure during one mission, 'went all to pieces.'
Attempts to pilot the plane in a desperate situation despite his own doubts.
Calmly communicates mayday and tries to manage the situation without panic.
